awd_titl_txt: RUI: Investigations of Mirror Coatings for A+ and Third Generation Gravitational Wave Detectors
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research in gravitational wave detector instrumentation and it addresses the priority areas of NSF's "Windows on the Universe" Big Idea. The Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) project has opened new windows to observe and understand the universe. The first direct detection of gravitational waves was also the first observation of the inspiral and merger of binary black holes. While black hole mergers are one of the most energetic events in the universe, they were not visible by electromagnetic telescopes. Now, after viewing several such observations, LIGO is developing a catalogue of the population of binary black hole systems. In addition, LIGO's observation of a binary neutron star merger inaugerated the field of multi-messenger astronomy. These simultaneous observations of gravitational waves and light allow for deeper insights into neutron star structure, and they allow us to test fundamental concepts like the speed of gravitational waves and the Hubble constant. The major challenges in this field are the noise sources that limit sensitivity, most notably thermal noise in LIGO's mirror coatings. LIGO is an interferometer, an L-shaped detector with 4 km long arms, which detects gravitational waves by observing tiny differential stretching in the arms. Identical light waves, emitted at the vertex, pass down each arm to a mirror and are reflected back. Any phase difference in the recombining beams corresponds to a difference in arm length. Thus detecting gravitational waves depends on the precision detection of the surface of the end mirrors, but for LIGO that precision is a daunting one billionth of an atom width. The mirrors, at room temperature (300 K), vibrate due to thermal energy at the mirror's resonant frequencies, which are much higher than the gravitational waves frequencies that LIGO can detect. If the mirrors were composed of an ideal elastic material, these vibrations could be ignored and of no concern. Indeed the fused silica glass used for the mirror substrates is a nearly ideal elastic material. However the highly reflective mirror coatings have internal friction that shifts some of the vibrational energy down to gravitational wave frequencies. That motion, which masks the gravitational wave signal, is mirror coating thermal noise (CTN). This research project is designed to understand and reduce CTN in order to improve LIGO's sensitivity. 

This project aims to reduce coating thermal noise by lowering the dissipation, or mechanical loss, in the coating materials. This dissipation occurs when a fluctuation in thermal or strain energy causes a dissipative state transition. This dissipative process is commonly modeled as an asymmetric double-well potential. The dissipation is reduced by increasing the energy asymmetry in the states, which lowers the transition probability. The team will investigate crystalline coatings, specifically AlGaAs, which has excellent optical properties. The AlGaAs elastic loss is very low for small samples, but further study is needed to understand the loss for large coatings. The team will also investigate stabilized amorphous dielectric coatings. Amorphous dielectric coatings produced by ion beam sputtering can have excellent optical properties, but they typically have high elastic loss. Annealing lowers the dissipation by allowing the material to relax into its lowest energy state. But annealing is limited by low crystallization temperature for these materials. Stabilized amorphous coatings are mixtures of dielectrics in which material mixture frustrates crystallization and allows a higher annealing temperature and lower elastic loss. The team will collaborate on experiments to test if the effects of annealing can be achieved by heating the substrate during deposition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The new and burgeoning field of gravitational wave astrophysics uses the knowledge gained from the observation of gravitational wave events to increase our understanding of the formation and structure of our universe and to answer fundamental questions of gravity.  These observations depend on the ability of instrument scientists to conduct the fundamental physics research that will allow gravitational wave (GW) detectors to regularly upgrade to increasingly better sensitivity.  These improvements allow the detectors to see farther out in the universe and correspondingly further back in time.  


This research project works to reduce mirror coating thermal noise (CTN), which is one of the two fundamental noise sources that limit GW detectors in the most sensitive central frequency region.  GW detectors are interferometers, "L" shaped detectors with 4 km (2.5 mile) arms.  GW’s that pass through the detector alternately stretch and squeeze the two arms causing an oscillation in the differential arm length.  This arm length difference is sensed by identical laser beams that travel down the arms, reflecting off end mirrors, and returning to the vertex. If the arms are of different length, the light from the two arms returns to the vertex slightly out of phase. This phase difference is the gravitational wave signal.  Coating thermal noise occurs because the mirror coating surface oscillates, driven by its thermal energy. (The detector operates at room temperature ≈ 300 K).  It is not possible to distinguish the average motion of the mirror surface from the motion of the optic, thus this thermal motion generates noise with an amplitude that is more than 1 million times larger than the displacement due to the gravitational wave.  The strategy for overcoming CTN is to use mirror materials for which the thermal motion is concentrated at frequencies well outside the band at which we detect gravitational waves.


The PI was part of the research team that first measured the CTN for LIGO mirrors and determined that it would be a limiting noise source.  The PI was the lead author on the paper that isolated the primary source of the noise.  And he was on the team that developed the Advanced LIGO mirror coatings with which LIGO made the first GW detection and hundreds more afterward.


The primary focus of this research project is further development of an improved mirror coating with reduced CTN that, along with a series of other improvements, will increase the GW detector sensitivity and the range at which it can detect GW events.  The most promising new coating candidate is a crystalline, semiconductor multilayer composed of gallium-arsenide (GaAs) and aluminum-gallium-arsenide (AlGaAs) that for brevity we call AlGaAs coatings.  These coatings have excellent optical properties and, most impressively, a 10 x reduction in CTN, which is far below the requirements for the next planned upgrade to the LIGO detector, known as LIGO A#.


Since crystalline coatings are a relatively new technology, it is imperative that these coatings be tested for all possible mechanisms that might add noise to the detector.  We have tested for the impact of electro-optic noise, but it is well below our noise limits.  It addition we are actively investigating the effects of birefringence and free carriers (electrons excited into the conduction band of the semiconductor) to see if they will impact detector noise.  Nothing of concern has been detected thus far.


One major concern had been scaling the production of these coatings to the 30-cm diameter required for the LIGO mirrors.  Currently production is limited to 20 cm, which is the maximum size available for the GaAs seed wafers on which the crystalline coatings are grown.   One recent advance in this project is a new effort to produce what are effectively 30-cm GaAs seed wafers by depositing GaAs on Germanium wafers, which are available in 30-cm.  There are currently 2 deposition methods being explored. Assuming that at least one method is successful, we anticipate the first 30-cm prototype sometime this winter.  That schedule would put us on track for providing AlGaAs coatings for LIGO's A# upgrade.
